Award.AwardTitle: Investigation of the Regulation of Annular Gap Junction Processing, a Critical Modulator of Cell-Cell Communication

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Neighboring cells need to communicate with one another in order to function properly, maintain proper organization of tissues, and make appropriate responses to changes in their environments. One method of communication involves the direct flow of information through membrane channels that are clustered on the surface of adjacent cells. These clusters of channels are called gap junction plaques and they are composed of proteins called connexin. The removal of gap junction plaques, from the cell surface, is critical to maintaining cell-to-cell communication and impacts numerous cellular functions, including proliferation, cell migration and differentiation. This project will elucidate the needed steps in gap junction plaque removal and determine the underlying molecular mechanisms. Increased information on annular gap junction processing and degradation could facilitate the development of new techniques to influence and control cell behavior, including proliferation and hormonal response. The PI will also continue to serve as a resource for the training of undergraduates, graduate students, and visiting professors from minority institutions. She used past NSF research funding to train forty-five undergraduates, eight graduate students, three postdoctoral fellows, seven visiting professors from minority institutions, five high school students, and ten medical students. Most of the students participating in this research over the years have been African-Americans, a severely under-represented group in science. She will also continue her broader outreach through publications, seminars, lectures and workshops for the scientific community and a unique outreach to the general public through art displays and lectures at a local art museum.

This project will investigate the mechanisms regulating annular gap junction processing. The PI hypothesizes that protein kinases via phosphorylation of sites on the C-terminal tail of the gap junction channel protein, connexin 43 (Cx43), play a pivotal role in annular gap junction vesicle processing needed for degradation. Such processing involves annular gap junction fissions as well as the formation of autophagasomes and multivesicular endosomes. Adrenal cortical cell populations will be used to elucidate the role of kinase-mediated Cx43 phosphorylation in annular gap junction processing and degradation. The approach will be to manipulate three kinases [protein kinase C (PKC), Src, cAMP-dependent protein kinase (PKA)] known to phosphorylate Cx43 and thought to be involved in annular gap junction degradation. In Objective I, To Measure the Annular Gap Junction Vesicle Degradative Process in Cell Populations in Which PKA, PKC, and Src Activities Have Been Altered. Three complementary methodologies will be used to selectively decrease or increase protein kinase activity: 1) chemical treatments with a panel of agents; 2) knockdown (siRNA) protocols; and 3) infection with replication-defective adenovirus vectors which result in constitutively activated kinases. In Objective II To Measure Annular Gap Junction Vesicle Degradative Process in Cells in Which the Cx43 Phosphorylation Sites Have Been Altered. Connexin mutation and truncation techniques will be used to modify the region of the intracellular "tail" of the Cx43 protein thought to be critical for kinase binding and/or phosphorylation. Throughout this study, annular gap junction processing (fission, formation of autophagasomes and multivesicular endosomes and fusion with other organelles (lysosomes, endosomes and plasma membranes [possible recycling of Cx43 to the plasma membrane]) will be investigated with immunocytochemical, quantum dot immuno-electron microscopy, western blot, and time lapse image analysis. Phospho-specific antibodies against the targeted sites are available and will be used to image the spacial and temporal distribution as well as protein amounts of the differing Cx43phosphoforms.The laboratory will continue to serve as a resource for the training of undergraduates, graduate students, and visiting professors from minority institutions. Students will be given a specific project and they will be encouraged to write and present their findings, both to the scientific community and to the general public. The PI will continue to make an impact on the scientific community through publications, seminars, lectures and workshops presented both nationally and internationally. In addition, lectures and installation art displays created, by the PI and displayed at a local art museum, will enable the PI to teach the general public about dynamic cellular events. It is hoped that information gained from this study and the training provided will serve to advance science and thus contribute to public welfare.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cells need to communicate with one another in order to function properly. One method of such communication involves the direct flow of information through membrane channels, known as gap junctions, that connect the cytoplasm of adjacent cells. These channels, which are composed of proteins called connexins, assemble at sites of cell-cell contacts to form gap junction plaques. While gap junction plaque assembly has been extensively studied, the disassembly and fate of their connexins are poorly understood, even though both the disassembly and assembly are critical to the regulation of cell-cell communication.  In this project, annular gap junction processing and the fate of connexin 43 (Cx43), the most abundantly expressed connexin protein type, were analyzed in adrenocortical and Sertoli cell populations. We hypothesized that protein kinases via phosphorylation of Cx43 play a pivotal role in annular gap junction vesicle processing. In this project, we characterized the steps in annular gap junction processing with combined imaging and molecular techniques in cells that were treated to alter Cx43 protein phosphorylation. We demonstrate clathrin/dynamin-dependent annular gap junction formation and the subsequent fusion of annular gap junctions with lysosomes, consistent the central dogma that gap junction plaque internalization being a mechanism for lysosome-dependent degradation of Cx43. In addition, however we documented the unexpected association of annular gap junctions with mitochondria, which occurred more often than their association with lysosomes. Mitochondrial/annular gap junction associations would be consistent with the possibility of annular gap junctions serving to deliver Cx43 to the mitochondria. Further, as part of collaborative efforts, we discovered endoplasmic reticulum sub-compartments, ribosome-associated vesicles (RAV) that form contacts with mitochondria. The finding of mitochondrial/RAV and mitochondrial/annular gap junction contacts could impact our understanding of mitochondrial function and protein delivery. Based Cx43 redistribution in dividing cells, in which gap junction plaques internalize at the onset of division but are rapid reestablishment toward the end of division from the annular gap junction pool, we suggest the intriguing possibility of annular gap junction Cx43 protein delivery (recycled) to the plasma membrane to form gap junction plaques as mitosis is completed. Our time-lapse observations of annular gap junctions contacting the plasma membrane further support the possibility of Cx43 recycling. Annular gap junction fissions into smaller annular gap junctions occurred significantly more often than contacts of annular gap junctions with the mitochondria, lysosomes or the plasma membrane. These fission events were decreased following treatments to activate protein kinase A (PKA) which was consistent with the finding of larger annular gap junctions in these treated populations compared to controls. In populations treated to activate protein kinase C (PKC) however there was an increase in gap junction plaque internalization events compared to control, which corresponded to more annular gap junctions. The number of gap junction fission events however were not altered significantly altered by PKC activation consistent with there not  being a difference in annular gap junction size in these populations compared to control, even though there were significant increases in Cx43 phosphorylation detected by western blot analysis. We suggest that while annular gap junction fission events are not influenced by PKC-mediated phosphorylation that gap junction plaque internalization events are increased which results in there being more annular gap junctions in the cytoplasm. The frequency and morphology of “atypical” annular gap junction structures were analyzed with super-resolution and transmission microscopy. Atypical annular gap junction structures were found to include annular gap junctions with a number of smaller vesicles within their lumen, cytoplasmic pentalaminar membrane aggregates, and bizarre structures with large inclusion within the annular gap junction lumen. Based on ultrastructural analysis however such structures are rare constituting (0.02%) of total number annular vesicles observed. Thus, we suggest that most of the puncta seen with live cell imaging and immunocytochemistry in our study represent annular gap junctions. From our studies, it is clear that annular gap junctions undergo processing events in addition to fusion with lysosomes for degradation. By elucidating the events in annular gap junction processing an understanding of gap junction plaque turnover and a wide variety of cellular functions in which cell-cell communication is involved will be increased. The information gained in this study will be useful not only for understanding of gap junction annular vesicle processing but also in understanding of vesicle dynamics, trafficking, and degradation. The Broader Impacts have been the increased participation and training in research and the creation of novel science-oriented art exhibits. Undergraduates and a postdoctoral fellow from the University of Pittsburgh along with faculty members from minority serving institutions have participated in this innovative research. They utilized cutting edge imaging tools to study protein dynamics and degradation. Installation art depicting protein dynamics has been exhibited at local art museums, with the intent of encouraging career paths in science while highlighting the beauty and intricacy of cells.
